{{Short description|A type of marketing strategy}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2014}} [[File:Sanford Health ambush marketing at Target Field.jpg|thumb|right|A billboard [[#Minneapolis sports venues|placed on]] the exterior of a [[Target Center|venue]] adjacent to [[Target Field]], so that it is visible from within to compete with a sponsorship held by a competitor.]]
'''Ambush marketing''' or '''ambush advertising''' is a [[marketing]] strategy in which an advertiser "[[wikt:ambush|ambushes]]" an event to compete for exposure against other advertisers.
The term "ambush marketing" was coined by marketing strategist Jerry Welsh, while he was working as the manager of global marketing efforts for [[American Express]] in the 1980s. Most ambush marketing campaigns capitalize on the prominence of a major event, and aim to create an "association" with the event without being an "official" partner or sponsor of the event. An advertiser may indirectly ambush an event by alluding to its imagery and [[Theme (narrative)|themes]] without referencing any specific [[trademark]]s associated with it, or in "direct" and "predatory" means—where an advertiser engages in conduct (including the fraudulent use of official names and trademarks) that mislead consumers into believing they are officially associated with the event.
Actions against ambush advertising are most common in [[sport]] (where major events such as the [[FIFA World Cup]], [[Olympic Games]], and the [[Super Bowl]] are prominent targets), as the practice can devalue and dilute exclusive sponsorship rights, and in some cases, infringe upon the organizers' [[intellectual property]] rights. Such actions may include restricting advertising in "clean zones" around an event site, removing or obscuring references to non-sponsors at venues, and requiring host countries to pass laws to grant the organizer legal rights to enforce clean zones, and to restrict the use of specific words and concepts to create unofficial associations with the event.
Anti-ambush marketing regulations have attracted controversy for limiting [[freedom of speech]], and for preventing companies from factually promoting themselves in the context of an event.
==Intent and techniques== Typically, ambush marketing is used to "[[Free rider problem|ride off]]" the prominence and draw of a major event, aligning promotional activities and publicity around it, without having to pay fees to the event's organizer to be designated as an "official" sponsor in a certain product category. Ambush marketing techniques can be classified into two categories: "direct" forms of ambush marketing involve advertisers promoting themselves as being a part of or associated with an event, diluting the exposure of official sponsors and their respective campaigns—especially if they are the product of the non-sponsor's competitors, while indirect forms of ambush marketing use imagery relating to an event in advertising to evoke a mental connection with it, without specifically mentioning it.<ref name=wsj-ambushed/><ref name=wsj-lining/>
"Predatory" forms of direct ambush marketing involve fraudulent claims by a non-sponsor that [[passing off|pass themselves off]] as being an "official" sponsor, usually by making direct references to [[trademark]]s relating to an event, but without having any official authorization from the event's organizers to identify itself as an official sponsor or use its trademarks.<ref name=wsj-ambushed>{{cite web|title=Ambushed!|url=https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052970204731804574391102699362862?mod=_newsreel_1|accessdate=7 October 2014|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=25 January 2010}}</ref> An advertiser may attempt to perform a [[publicity stunt]] inside the venue itself to attract attention to their brand, such as having attendees wear attire that is associated with the company.<ref name="guardian-2010skirt"/><ref name="bbc-shorts"/><ref name=wsj-ambushed /> An official sponsor can also be involved in direct ambush marketing if they perform more extensive promotional activities at an event than they were originally authorized, such as distributing branded merchandise when they were only granted advertising on signage—especially if these activities compete with those of another sponsor authorized to do so.<ref name=wsj-ambushed />
A company may also perform direct ambush marketing by [[Wikt:ride the coattails|riding coattails]]—factually marketing their role in connection to an event or its participants. For example, a company which produces sporting equipment may advertise that they are the official supplier for a specific athlete or team.<ref name=wsj-lining/><ref name=wsj-ambushed/> Similarly, a non-sponsor may choose to solely sponsor the event's telecast by a broadcaster, but not the event itself.<ref name=bbc-ambushed /> The factual acknowledgment of a non-sponsor's involvement with the participants in an event by, for example, a television host or commentator, can also be considered an incidental form of coattail marketing, as it provides additional unpaid publicity to the brand.<ref name=wsj-lining/><ref name=wsj-ambushed/>
Most forms of indirect ambush marketing involve a non-sponsor making use of imagery, [[Theme (narrative)|themes]], and [[values]] similar to what the event and campaigns from official sponsors express, either positively or negatively, and without making specific references to the event itself or its trademarks. In essence, the advertiser markets itself using content that evokes a mental association with the event, and as a result, appeals to those who are aware of the event.<ref name=sportpro-ambush>{{cite web|title=Rise of the pseudo-sponsors: A history of ambush marketing|url=http://www.sportspromedia.com/notes_and_insights/rise_of_the_pseudo-sponsors_a_history_of_ambush_marketing|website=SportPro|accessdate=3 January 2015}}</ref><ref name=wsj-ambushed/> Advertisers may use a well-known nickname for the event that is not a trademark, such as "the big game".<ref name=thr-supertrademarks>{{cite web|title=Super Bowl, Super Trademarks: Protecting the NFL's IP|url=http://www.hollywoodreporteresq.com/thresq/ip/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003538980|website=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=30 January 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070526064231/http://www.hollywoodreporteresq.com/thresq/ip/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003538980|archivedate=26 May 2007|date=29 January 2007}}</ref>
Similarly, a non-sponsor may use "distractive" techniques to divert consumers' attention away from the actual event and its official sponsors using similarly indirect means; for example, a non-sponsor may saturate the area at or around its venue (including [[street vendor]]s, billboards, and [[public transport]]) with a competing marketing presence. Such "saturation marketing" may either be indirectly related to the event, or be incidental and make no references at all. In some cases, a company may sponsor or create a similar "parallel property," designed to compete directly with a major property by evoking similar thematics.<ref name=wsj-ambushed/>
== Regulation == In response to the threats of ambush marketing and other forms of [[trademark infringement]], organizers of major sporting events have sometimes required host countries or cities to implement special laws that, going beyond standard [[trademark law]], provide regulations and penalties for advertisers who disseminate marketing materials that create unauthorized associations with an event by making references to specific words, concepts, and symbols.<ref name=guardian-olympicbill/><ref name=startrib-aclu/> Organizers may also require a city to set up "clean zones" in and around venues, in which advertising and commerce is restricted to those that are authorized by the event's organizer—specifically, the event's official sponsors.<ref name=aclu-nosuperbowl>{{cite web|title=ACLU Sues City of New Orleans Over Super Bowl "Clean Zone" Ordinance|url=https://www.aclu.org/free-speech/aclu-sues-city-new-orleans-over-super-bowl-clean-zone-ordinance|publisher=ACLU|accessdate=15 October 2014}}</ref><ref name=vice-nosuperbowl>{{cite web|title=Clean Zones and Cabbies: How the Super Bowl Screws New Orleans Part 2|url=https://www.vice.com/en_ca/read/clean-zones-and-cabbies-how-the-super-bowl-screws-new-orleans-part-2|accessdate=15 October 2014|work=Vice}}</ref><ref name=dmn-lawsuit>{{cite web|title=Super Bowl host committee settles 'ambush marketing' lawsuit|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/local-news/20120906-super-bowl-host-committee-settles-ambush-marketing-lawsuit.ece|accessdate=15 October 2014|work=Dallas Morning News|date=6 September 2014}}</ref>
In some cases, a venue may be required to suspend its [[naming rights]] for the duration of the event if the venue is named for a concern that is not an official sponsor, during which it is referred to under a generic name by all event-related materials and telecasts, and all signage referring to the sponsored name may be obscured or removed.<ref name=louw-ambush>{{cite book|last1=Louw|first1=Andre M.|title=Ambush marketing and the mega-event monopoly how laws are abused to protect commercial rights to major sporting events|date=2012|publisher=T. M. C. Asser Press|location=The Hague, The Netherlands|isbn=978-90-6704-864-4}}</ref> For example, [[2010 Winter Olympics]] hockey venue General Motors Place (since renamed to [[Rogers Arena]]) was renamed "Canada Hockey Place" for the duration of the Games.<ref name=cbc-rogersarena>{{cite web|title=GM Place renamed Rogers Arena|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/gm-place-renamed-rogers-arena-1.923708|website=CBC News|accessdate=10 July 2015}}</ref>
Broadcasters of events may be contractually required to give the official sponsors [[right of first refusal]] to purchase advertising time during their telecasts.<ref name=wsj-ambushed /><ref name=wsj-logotape>{{cite web|title=Ignore That Logo Under the Tape!|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB121885240984946511|accessdate=10 July 2015|work=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref> Some events may require all advertising time to be controlled and allocated by the organizer itself, such as the [[UEFA Champions League]].<ref name=sportpro-ambush />
=== Examples === The earliest example of general anti-ambush advertising legislation were passed in [[South Africa]] in 2001 in preparation for the [[2003 Cricket World Cup]]. The law gave the Minister of Trade and Industry the ability to designate specific events as "protected," making it illegal to use the event's trademarks visually, audibly, and "in promotional activities, which in any way, directly or indirectly, is intended to be brought into association with or to allude to an event," to "derive special promotional benefit from the event," without the consent of the organizer.<ref name="louw 2012">{{cite book|last1=Louw|first1=Andre M.|title=Ambush marketing and the mega-event monopoly how laws are abused to protect commercial rights to major sporting events|date=2012|publisher=T. M. C. Asser Press|location=The Hague, The Netherlands|isbn=906704864X}}</ref> Prior to the [[2011 Rugby World Cup]], [[New Zealand]] passed the similar "Major Events Management Act," which prohibits any promotional use of words, emblems, and concepts implying association with events specifically designated as "major" by the national government, without permission from the event's organizers. The law also provides the ability for clean zones to be established around event sites for the purposes of enforcing advertising rules and providing [[crowd control]].<ref name=tvnz-threelittlewords>{{cite web|title=Warning over three little words|url=http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/warning-over-three-little-words-3694792|website=One News|publisher=TVNZ|accessdate=30 September 2014}}</ref><ref name=nzl-mema>{{cite web|title=Major Events Management Act 2007|url=http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/2007/0035/latest/DLM411987.html|website=Leglislation.govt.nz|accessdate=30 September 2014}}</ref><ref name=aucklandnow-rwcact>{{cite web|title=Rugby World Cup advertising ambush expected|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/auckland/local-news/5297879/Rugby-World-Cup-advertising-ambush-expected|accessdate=30 September 2014|work=Auckland Now}}</ref>
[[Rule 40]] of the [[Olympic Charter]] forbids all Olympic athletes from participating in marketing activities for companies that are not official sponsors of the Olympics, even if they have official relationships with the advertiser, during a timeframe that begins 9 days before the opening ceremony, and ends 3 days after the Games' conclusion. This includes advertising material containing "Olympic-related terms," including the current year, the host city's name, "Games," "Olympians," "Sponsors," "Medal," "Gold," "Silver," "Bronze," "Challenge," "Effort," "Performance," and "Victory".<ref name="bbcsport-rule40">{{cite web|title=Rio Olympics 2016: Athletes could face sanctions over controversial rule 40|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/olympics/36909409|website=BBC Sport|accessdate=2 August 2016}}</ref>
The [[United Kingdom]] passed the [[London Olympic Games and Paralympic Games Act 2006]] prior to the [[2012 Summer Olympics]]: on top of existing laws providing special protection for [[Olympic symbols]], the act banned the use of the words "2012" and "Games" by non-sponsors, either together, or with words or concepts relating to the event, such as "Gold," "Silver," "Bronze," "Medals," "Summer," "Sponsors," or "London," to imply an association with the Games. LOCOG also announced plans to enforce these rules in the internet [[keyword advertising]] market.<ref name=mondaq-keyword>{{cite web|title=UK: LOCOG To Police Keyword Bidding In Run Up To London 2012|url=http://www.mondaq.com/x/141722/Advertising+Marketing/LOCOG+To+Police+Keyword+Bidding+In+Run+Up+To+London+2012|website=Mondaq|accessdate=24 October 2014}}</ref><ref name=guardian-brandingpolice />
==Examples== === The "credit card wars" === The first notable instances of ambush marketing occurred between the [[1984 Summer Olympics]] in Los Angeles, and the [[1988 Summer Olympics]] in Seoul.<ref name=sportpro-ambush /> Earlier Games allowed any number of companies to be official sponsors, and there were a record 628 sponsors for the [[1976 Summer Olympics]] in Montreal. Despite the revenue it provided for the Games, the ability for sponsors to promote awareness of themselves within the context of the Games were diluted by the sheer number.<ref name=sportpro-ambush /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/radio/undertheinfluence/marketing-the-olympics-1.2801785|title=Marketing The Olympics|work=CBC Radio|access-date=2018-08-06}}</ref> In order to improve the value of these sponsorships, the [[International Olympic Committee]] implemented a system of exclusive sponsorship rights within specific market categories for the 1984 Summer Olympics.<ref name=sportpro-ambush />
In 1986, [[credit card]] company [[American Express]]—rival to official sponsor [[Visa Inc.]], began a marketing campaign in Asia promoting merchandise from a fictitious "Olympic Heritage Committee," supposedly based in Switzerland. American Express halted the campaign following complaints by the IOC, who threatened to denounce the company's actions with ads and media events in which [[sports minister]]s and Olympic athletes from the countries involved in the campaign would cut American Express [[credit card]]s into pieces, if they did not withdraw the ads.<ref name=sportpro-ambush /> In a follow-up, American Express released ads featuring a photo from the opening ceremony of the [[1986 Asian Games]] held in the same city, captioned "Amex welcomes you to Seoul," which implied that it was a photo of the Olympics' opening ceremony.<ref name=sportpro-ambush /><ref name=reuters-creditcardwar/> These campaigns resulted in retaliatory advertising from Visa.; in a continuation of an ongoing campaign promoting its exclusivity at certain venues and events, Visa ran advertising promoting that it was the only credit card accepted at Olympic venues and for purchasing tickets.<ref name=sportpro-ambush /><ref name="lat-ambushes">{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-03-28/business/fi-4230_1_american-express|title=Credit Companies Trade Charges: Visa and American Express clash over using the Olympics in their promotions.|last=Gellene|first=Denise|date=1992-03-28|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2017-10-26}}</ref><ref name=tribune-dontneedavisa/><ref name=reuters-creditcardwar>{{cite web|title=Credit Card War Erupts at Olympics: Advertising: IOC accuses American Express Co. of 'ambush marketing' in campaign aimed at rival Visa.|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1994-02-19/business/fi-24757_1_american-express|accessdate=6 January 2015|agency=Reuters|date=19 February 1994}}</ref>
American Express felt that Visa's advertisements were misleading, citing viewers who interpreted the ads as to believe that no other credit cards were accepted anywhere in the host city during the Olympics (such as at shops and restaurants), rather than applying only for Olympic ticket sales and at venues.<ref name="lat-ambushes"/> Prior to the [[1992 Winter Olympics]] and [[1992 Summer Olympics|Summer Olympics]], American Express aired advertisements acknowledging these facts, explained with the tagline "You'll need a [[passport]], but you don't need a Visa."<ref name=reuters-creditcardwar/><ref name=tribune-dontneedavisa>{{cite web|title=Visa, American Express Play Negative-ad Card|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1994-10-30/business/9410300124_1_visa-usa-american-express-cardholders/2|accessdate=6 January 2015|work=Chicago Tribune|date=30 October 1994}}</ref> Prior to the 1992 Summer Olympics, the company also promoted a partnership with [[Iberia (airline)|Iberia]] and Turespana that made American Express "the official credit card of tourism in Spain"—a campaign which factored the Olympics, as well as [[Seville Expo '92]].<ref name="lat-ambushes"/> The IOC negotiated a truce between Amex and Visa to tone down their advertisements, but encouraged Visa once Amex returned to its ambush marketing in 1994, and Amex finally conceded defeat by 1996.<ref name=sportpro-ambush/> Jerry Welsh, who was the manager of global marketing efforts for American Express in the 1980s, would coin the term "ambush marketing" to refer to these activities. Welsh defended Amex's practices as a corporation's duty to its shareholders after they lost out on the official Olympic sponsorship rights to Visa.<ref name=sportpro-ambush/>
=== Nike === In the mid 1990s, [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] became known for several major ambush marketing schemes at the Olympics and association football tournaments.
At the [[1996 Summer Olympics]], Nike (whose presence competed with official sponsor [[Reebok]]) set up a prominent [[pop-up store]] near the athletes' village. Consistent with its aggressively-toned marketing of the time, its campaign featured slogans parodying those of the Olympics and attacking its values, including "Faster, Higher, Stronger, Badder", and "If you're not here to win, you're a tourist". Nike was also attempting to have fans to display signs with its slogans inside venues. IOC marketing director [[Michael Payne (executive)|Michael Pane]] noted that the campaign was being widely criticized, as athletes were "likely to be uncomfortable when their shoe sponsor says they have failed unless they win a gold medal", and that Nike was "crossing the very fine line between having an impact and biting the hand that creates tomorrow's heroes."<ref name=sportpro-ambush />
Payne and the [[United States Olympic Committee]]'s marketing director John Krimsky held a meeting over the campaign with Howard Slusher, a subordinate of Nike co-founder [[Phil Knight]]. The meeting quickly turned aggressive; Payne threatened IOC counter-measures, including pulling accreditation for Nike employees, banning the display of its logos on equipment, and organizing a press conference where silver medallists from the Games, as well as prominent Nike-sponsored athlete [[Michael Johnson (sprinter)|Michael Johnson]], would denounce the company. Faced with these threats, Nike agreed to retract most of its negative advertising and PR stunts.<ref name=sportpro-ambush /> Nike eventually served as the official sportswear supplier of the [[2000 Summer Olympics]] on short notice after Reebok unexpectedly pulled out, and used the Games to launch its first-ever global marketing campaign.<ref name=sportpro-ambush />
Nike also performed saturation ambushes at [[UEFA Euro 1996]] and the [[1998 FIFA World Cup]], by buying advertising space in the vicinity of the host venues in order to prevent the official sponsors ([[Umbro]] and [[Adidas]] respectively) from being able to promote themselves. Nike's actions influenced the eventual adoption of "safe zone" rules, requiring official sponsors to have exclusive use of all advertising locations within a certain radius of an event's venue.<ref name=sportpro-ambush />
=== FIFA World Cup === During a game at the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]], fans were asked to remove "[[Leeuwenhosen]]"—pants with [[lion]] tails colored in the orange of the [[Netherlands national football team]], distributed and branded by [[Bavaria Brewery (Netherlands)|Bavaria Brewery]]—because they infringed on the exclusive beer sponsorship rights owned by [[Anheuser-Busch]]. Officials distributed orange-colored shorts to fans affected by the requirement.<ref name="bbc-shorts">{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/5104252.stm|title=Dutch fans given shorts for match|publisher=[[BBC News]] | date=21 June 2006 | accessdate=7 May 2010}}</ref> Bavaria Brewery was again accused of ambush marketing at the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]], when 36 female fans were ejected from a game (along with the arrest of two, later released, accused of violating the Contravention of Merchandise Marks Act) for wearing unbranded orange [[miniskirts]] that were provided by Bavaria; [[Sylvie van der Vaart]], wife of Dutch player [[Rafael van der Vaart]], had modeled one of the miniskirts in an advertising campaign for the brewery.<ref name="guardian-2010skirt">{{cite web| url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/jun/16/fifa-world-cup-ambush-marketing | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=World Cup 2010: Women arrested over 'ambush marketing' freed on bail | first=Owen | last=Gibson | date=16 June 2010}}</ref><ref name="bbc-ambushed">{{cite web | last =Kelly | first =Jon | title =How ambush marketing ambushed sport | work =BBC News Magazine | publisher =BBC | date =17 June 2010 | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/magazine/8743881.stm | accessdate =2010-06-21 }}</ref> [[Robbie Earle]] was also fired from his roles as [[ITV Sport]] pundit and ambassador for [[England 2018 FIFA World Cup bid|England's bid for the 2018 World Cup]], when it was claimed by FIFA that he had sold tickets meant for family and friends on to Bavaria.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment_and_arts/10322048.stm |title=Robbie Earle sacked over World Cup tickets |date=16 June 2010 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=16 June 2010 }}</ref>
Prior to the 2010 FIFA World Cup, South African budget airline [[Kulula]] ran an advertisement that played upon the fact that they were not an official sponsor of the tournament: it described themselves as "Unofficial National Carrier of the You-Know-What," and contained images of stadiums, [[Ball (association football)|balls]], [[vuvuzela]]s and national flags. The ad was pulled following a complaint by FIFA, who claimed that the ads contained symbols that constituted an unauthorized association with the event when used together.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/8576220.stm | work=BBC News | title=Fifa orders SA airline to pull ad | date=19 March 2010}}</ref> Kulula mocked FIFA's objections in subsequent advertising: a follow-up ad deliberately replaced the items from the first ad with similarly-shaped items (such as [[disco ball]]s and [[golf tee]]s), and explained that there were other reasons to travel South Africa "than just for that thing we wouldn't dare mention."<ref name="time-wouldntdaremention">{{cite web|title=Stopping Ambush Marketers During the World Cup|url=http://content.time.com/time/business/article/0,8599,1978129,00.html|website=Time|accessdate=8 February 2016}}</ref> The airline also announced that it would give away free flights to anyone named "[[Sepp Blatter]]"; the offer was redeemed for a dog named after the then-[[FIFA president]].<ref name=best-ambush>{{cite web|title=Ingenious Ambush Campaigns From Nike, Samsung and BMW Make Official Sponsorships Look Like A Waste|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/best-ambush-marketing-campaigns-2012-6?op=1|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=18 August 2012}}</ref>
=== Olympic Games === [[File:Li_Ling_during_2008_Summer_Olympics_opening_ceremony.jpg|thumb|140px|right|[[Li Ning]] carrying the torch at the [[2008 Summer Olympics opening ceremony|opening ceremony]] of the [[2008 Summer Olympics]].]]
The [[International Olympic Committee]] has required host cities to enact measures to restrict commerce around venues, ensure official sponsors have access to public advertising space, "reduce and sanction" ambush marketing, and keep venues "clean" of any references to non-sponsors.<ref name=louw-ambush/>
At the [[2008 Summer Olympics]] in Beijing, the IOC worked with the local organizing committee to develop a "robust brand-protection program"; logos of non-sponsors were covered with [[Adhesive tape|tape]] on equipment at Games facilities—a restriction that applied even to appliances, bathroom fixtures, elevators, and fire extinguishers.<ref name=wsj-logotape/> However, there was a high-profile ambush during the [[2008 Summer Olympics opening ceremony|opening ceremony]]; former Olympic gymnast [[Li Ning]], who founded [[Li-Ning|an eponymous Chinese shoe company]], lit the Olympic cauldron. The Li-Ning company was not an official sponsor of the Games (but did act as an equipment supplier for some of [[China at the 2008 Summer Olympics|China's teams]]), and Li wore [[Adidas]] appeal for the sequence per its official sponsorship.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2008-08-11/olympic-ambush-heats-up-li-ning-adidas-rivalrybusinessweek-business-news-stock-market-and-financial-advice|title=Olympic Ambush Heats Up Li Ning-Adidas Rivalry|date=2008-08-11|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-10-21}}</ref><ref name=wsj-lining>{{cite web|title=A Torchbearer's Commercial Coup|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB121825465626927001?mod=googlenews_wsj|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=18 August 2012}}</ref> On the first trading day following the ceremony, Li-Ning's share price increased by 3.52%.<ref name="Newsweek">{{cite news |last = Liu|first = Melinda|title = Light My Fire: Li Ning's Stock Rises|date = August 12, 2008|publisher = Newsweek|url = http://blog.newsweek.com/blogs/beijingolympics/archive/2008/08/12/light-my-fire-li-ning-s-stock-rises.aspx|archivedate=18 August 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080818080815/http://www.blog.newsweek.com/blogs/beijingolympics/archive/2008/08/12/light-my-fire-li-ning-s-stock-rises.aspx|dead-url=true}}</ref>
Prior to the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] in London, England, [[bookmaker]] [[Paddy Power]] organized an [[egg-and-spoon race]] in the French village of [[London, Burgundy]] with a €100 credit as a prize, allowing the company to jokingly market itself as being the official sponsor of "the largest athletics event in London this year".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bettingpro.com/category/industry-news/paddy-power-sponsors-egg-spoon-race-201207240050/|title=Paddy Power sponsor 2012 Olympics Egg & Spoon Race|website=Bettingpro.com|access-date=2018-08-13}}</ref><ref name=pp-ad/> LOCOG threatened Paddy Power over ads for the event, but backtracked after Paddy Power threatened to take the organizing committee to court.<ref name=pp-ad>{{cite web|title=London 2012 Olympics: Paddy Power seek a court order after Locog demand advertising posters be taken down|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/9425878/London-2012-Olympics-Paddy-Power-seek-a-court-order-after-Locog-demand-advertising-posters-be-taken-down.html|publisher=Telegraph|accessdate=18 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=LOCOG U-turns over Paddy Power 'London' ads|url=http://www.marketingmagazine.co.uk/News/MostRead/1142903/LOCOG-U-turns-Paddy-Power-London-ads/|publisher=Marketing Magazine|accessdate=18 August 2012}}</ref> When announcing the planned lawsuit, a Paddy Power spokesmen quipped that "It's a pity they didn't put the same energy in to the ticketing and [[Security for the 2012 Summer Olympics|security arrangements]] for the Games that they put into protecting their sponsorship revenue streams."<ref name=pp-ad/> Nike released a television advert tying into the Games with a similar concept, featuring footage of athletes training in [[London (disambiguation)|other places named "London"]], and the tagline "Greatness doesn't only exist in [[SW19]]".<ref name=guardian-nikelondon>{{cite web|title=London 2012 Olympics will not take legal action over Nike ad campaign|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/jul/27/london-olympics-legal-action-nike|accessdate=4 January 2015|work=The Guardian}}</ref> Following the Games, a study by the [[Global Language Monitor]] found that several non-sponsors, including [[Centrica]], [[Ericsson]], [[Philips]], and [[Subway (restaurant)|Subway]], were among the brands with the highest perceived relationship between themselves and the Games.<ref name=glm-bai2012>{{cite web|title=Olympic Ambush Marketers Continue to Dominate London 2012|url=http://www.languagemonitor.com/olympics/olympic-ambush-marketers-continue-to-dominate-london-2012/|website=Global Language Monitor|accessdate=3 January 2015}}</ref>
In January 2014, prior to the [[2014 Winter Olympics]], clothing company [[The North Face]] was sued by the [[Canadian Olympic Committee]] (COC) for marketing a line of "villagewear" apparel that it felt implied an unauthorized association with the Games. The apparel had designs featuring the colors and symbols of countries (such as red and white with a [[maple leaf]] for Canada) and patches reading "[[Russia|RU]] 14," were described in a catalog as "[capturing] the international spirit of the Olympic Games," and several items in the catalog contained references to [[Sochi]] in their names. The COC also felt that the name "villagewear" implied a reference to [[Olympic Village]]s, accused the company of using the [[Olympic rings]] in a store sign advertising the line, and purporting to give away tickets to the Games as part of a contest—in violation of terms and conditions restricting redistribution of tickets without permission.<ref name=gandm-villagewear/><ref name=tsn-northface/> The North Face disputed the COC's claims, arguing that it did not imply it was an official supporter of the COC, did not use any of the official branding elements of the Games, that the COC had no right to restrict usage of national symbols that are in the [[public domain]], and that the COC did not hold rights to the "alleged Olympic trademarks" at all since they were owned by the IOC. The suit went to trial in December 2014.<ref name=tsn-northface>{{cite web|title=Canadian Olympic 'ambush marketing' battle heading to trial|url=https://www.tsn.ca/canadian-olympic-ambush-marketing-battle-heading-to-trial-1.160194|website=TSN.ca|accessdate=3 February 2015}}</ref><ref name=gandm-villagewear>{{cite web|title=Canadian Olympic Committee threatens North Face with trademark suit|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/industry-news/the-law-page/canadian-olympic-committee-threatens-to-sue-north-face-for-trademark-infringement/article16439709/|accessdate=3 February 2015|work=The Globe and Mail}}</ref>
Prior to the [[2016 Summer Olympics]], Rule 40 was loosened by the IOC to allow some campaigns by non-sponsors involving athletes to occur during the Games, as long as the campaign had begun within a certain timeframe prior to the Games, and do not imply an association with the Olympics. It also requires the submission of waivers to the IOC and the country's [[National Olympic Committee]] that describe the extent of the marketing involving athletes.<ref name="nyt-evade"/><ref name="adweek-2016"/> Prior to these Games, the [[United States Olympic Committee]] (USOC) also issued a warning asserting that non-sponsors could not create or disseminate any content related to the Olympics on social media, including posts referencing the Games or its results, posts sourced from official accounts, or posts using official [[hashtag]]s (which the USOC has claimed as trademarks).<ref name="techdirt-dearusoc">{{cite web|title=Dear US Olympic Committee: Tweeting About The Olympics Is Never Trademark Infringement|url=https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20160722/07140335039/dear-us-olympic-committee-tweeting-about-olympics-is-never-trademark-infringement.shtml|website=Techdirt|accessdate=26 July 2016}}</ref><ref name="guardian-usochashtags">{{cite web|title=US Olympic committee bullying unofficial sponsors who use hashtags|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/jul/22/us-olympic-committee-bullying-unofficial-sponsors-hashtags|website=The Guardian|accessdate=25 July 2016}}</ref><ref name="espn-usocambush">{{cite web|title=United States Olympic Committee in battle with athletes and the companies that sponsor them but not Olympics|url=http://espn.go.com/olympics/story/_/id/17120510/united-states-olympic-committee-battle-athletes-companies-sponsor-not-olympics|website=ESPN.com|accessdate=25 July 2016}}</ref>
In July 2016, the [[Australian Olympic Committee]] sued mobile provider [[Telstra]] over adverts promoting its partnership with the [[Seven Network]] to offer subscribers free premium access to its digital [[Olympics on Seven|coverage]] of the 2016 Summer Olympics, as the broadcaster's "official technology partner". The ad was set to a version of [[Peter Allen (musician)|Peter Allen]]'s song "[[I Go to Rio]]"—a phrase which was also used as the tagline of the campaign. The AOC argued that the promotion was deceiving and could imply that Telstra was an official sponsor of the Australian Olympic team (Telstra was previously an official sponsor, but ended its relationship in 2015). Telstra defended the ads, stating that they were intended to promote its relationship with the official broadcaster, and that it would amend the ads to disclaim that the company is not an official sponsor of the AOC or any related entities.<ref name="smh-telstradeceive">{{cite web|title=Australian Olympic Committee sues Telstra over 'I go to Rio' ads|url=http://www.smh.com.au/business/media-and-marketing/australian-olympic-committee-sues-telstra-over-i-go-to-rio-ads-20160715-gq6y8m.html|website=Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=22 August 2016|date=15 July 2016}}</ref><ref name="newscomau-telstrawins">{{cite web|title=Telstra wins case against the Australian Olympic Committee on its ‘I go to Rio’ campaign|url=http://www.news.com.au/sport/olympics/telstra-wins-case-against-the-australian-olympic-committee-on-its-i-go-to-rio-campaign/news-story/99c8975f78cf202398229bc5d46b7ab6|website=News.com.au|accessdate=22 August 2016}}</ref> On 29 July 2016, a federal court ruled in favor of Telstra, stating that there was "no doubt" the campaign was relating to the Games without using its trademarks, but that it was "not enough for the AOC to prove that the advertisements were Olympic-themed."<ref name="smh-telstrawins">{{cite web|title=Telstra 'Go to Rio' campaign cleared by Federal Court, AOC case dismissed|url=http://www.smh.com.au/business/media-and-marketing/telstra-go-to-rio-campaign-cleared-by-federal-court-20160729-gqgojk.html|website=Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=22 August 2016}}</ref>
The IOC's restrictive ambush marketing rules were one factor in the [[National Hockey League]]'s decision to ban its players from the [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics|2018 Olympics]]; for the previous five Olympics, the NHL scheduled an extended break in the regular season to allow players to participate, and placed its [[NHL All-Star Game|All-Star Game]] on hiatus. The NHL noted that the rules disallowed teams from promoting their players' participation in the tournament.<ref name="NYTimes20160520">{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/20/sports/hockey/olympics-and-nhl-face-off-over-who-pays-to-insure-players.html?_r=0 | title=Olympics and N.H.L. Face Off Over Who Pays to Insure Players | work=The New York Times | date=19 May 2016 | accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref>
=== NFL === The [[National Football League]] has historically been protective over unauthorized uses of its intellectual property, such as the game telecasts themselves, and most notably, its trademark for the [[Super Bowl]]—the league's championship game. To protect these properties and its official sponsors, the league has historically sent reminders and [[cease and desist]] notices to advertisers and businesses—including establishments that may be showing the game—that use references to "Super Bowl," "Super Sunday," or team names in promotional activities related to the Super Bowl. Although using part of a trademark for descriptive purposes, without implying official association, can be considered a [[nominative use]] under [[United States trademark law]], non-sponsors typically use euphemisms such as "the Big Game" to refer to the Super Bowl in advertising to protect themselves from liability.<ref name=thr-supertrademarks/><ref name=ars-nfloveraggressive /><ref name=wsj-godvsgridiron>{{cite web|title=God vs. Gridiron|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB120190701069036633?mod=home_we_banner_left|accessdate=30 January 2015|work=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref> In 2006, the NFL submitted an application to register "The Big Game" as a trademark as well, but withdrew following opposition by students of [[Stanford University]] and [[University of California, Berkeley|UC Berkeley]], who play in a long-running [[college football]] [[rivalry game]] also known as "[[Big Game (American football)|the Big Game]]"—an event which pre-dates the Super Bowl by several decades.<ref>{{cite web |last=FitzGerald |first=Tom |title=NFL sidelines its pursuit of Big Game trademark |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/05/23/SPGUAQ07LN6.DTL | work=The San Francisco Chronicle | date=22 August 2010}}</ref> The NFL has also partaken in clean zone policies around Super Bowl sites to protect against saturation ambush marketing.<ref name=vice-nosuperbowl />
The [[XFL]]—a forthcoming rival league, floated a large [[blimp]] branded with the logos of the league and its equipment supplier [[Spalding (sports equipment)|Spalding]], over the [[Oakland Coliseum]] during an [[Oakland Raiders]] playoff game on January 6, 2000. The league intended to do so again on January 14 for the AFC championship game, but on the 9th, the blimp was let loose unmanned after a failed attempt to land it at [[Oakland International Airport]], and it crashed over a waterfront restaurant on the [[Oakland Estuary]] after getting caught on a sailboat mast. The blimp sustained US$2.5 million worth of damage,<ref>{{cite web|date=January 31, 2001|title=Blimp crashes into Oakland restaurant|work=ESPN.com|url=http://espn.go.com/moresports/news/2001/0110/1005983.html|accessdate=2010-07-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/XFL-S-UNPLANNED-TOUCHDOWN-Wayward-blimp-s-wild-2966749.php|title=XFL'S UNPLANNED TOUCHDOWN / Wayward blimp's wild, woolly flight ends in Oakland crash|work=SFGate|access-date=2017-10-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|date=January 10, 2001|title=XFL'S UNPLANNED TOUCHDOWN / Wayward blimp's wild, woolly flight ends in Oakland crash|newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|publisher=[[Hearst Communications]]|url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/XFL-S-UNPLANNED-TOUCHDOWN-Wayward-blimp-s-wild-2966749.php|accessdate=November 23, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|date=January 10, 2001|title=Crash Mouth Football: XFL Promo Blimp In Bay Area Deflates|publisher=Sports Business Daily|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Daily/Issues/2001/01/Issue-76/Sponsorships-Advertising-Marketing/Crash-Mouth-Football-XFL-Promo-Blimp-In-Bay-Area-Deflates.aspx|newspaper=Sports Business Daily|accessdate=November 23, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Smith |first1=Martin J. |last2=Kiger |first2=Patrick J. |date=2006 |title=Oops: 20 Life Lessons from the Fiascoes That Shaped America |location=New York |publisher=Collins |page=218 |isbn=0-06-078083-5 }}</ref> and the incident was later considered to be an [[omen]] for the XFL's eventual failure.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timesunion.com/sports/article/Vasgersian-s-has-enjoyed-varied-broadcast-career-13264386.php|title=Vasgersian's has enjoyed varied broadcast career|date=2018-09-27|work=Times Union|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://tv.avclub.com/30-for-30-shrugs-at-the-train-wreck-that-was-the-xfl-1798190234|title=30 For 30 shrugs at the train wreck that was the XFL|last=Murray|first=Noel|work=The A.V. Club|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref>
In 2009 and 2010, [[Avid Life Media]] produced advertisements for its [[extramarital]] and [[homosexual]] [[online dating service]]s [[Ashley Madison]] and [[ManCrunch]], that it aimed to have [[Super Bowl advertising|aired during]] the Super Bowl. The Ashley Madison ad featured the tagline "Who Are You Doing After the Game?," while the ManCrunch ad culminated with two male football fans kissing and [[dry humping]] each other. Both ads were rejected by the game's respective broadcasters; the Ashley Madison ad for objectionable content, and the ManCrunch ad for its unauthorized use of NFL trademarks. An Avid Life Media spokesperson, as well as the media, initially reported that the ManCrunch ad had actually been rejected because of its homosexual themes.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bartlett|first1=Kristen|title=How Ashley Madison ruined my reputation (on purpose) long before the hack.|url=http://happyplace.someecards.com/workplace/ashley-madison-avid-life-media-super-bowl-homophobic-ad/|accessdate=22 July 2015|publisher=[[Someecards]]|date=21 July 2015}}</ref> Critics felt that the company was engaging in ambush marketing by intentionally submitting ads that would be rejected by broadcasters, and thus earn free publicity from the resulting "controversy" without having to pay for the ad time itself. The company denied this was the case, and stated that it had serious intentions to purchase the ad time if the commercials were approved.<ref name=nydailynews>{{cite web| last=Hill| first=Catey | date=29 January 2009|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/money/2009/01/28/2009-01-28_banned_these_ads_are_too_racy_for_the_su-1.html|title= Banned! These ads are too racy for the Super Bowl|work=[[The New York Daily News]]| accessdate= 6 January 2010}}</ref><ref name=fancast-mancrunch>{{cite web|last=Phillips|first=Tracy|title=CBS Rejects Gay Dating Site’s Super Bowl Ad|url=http://www.fancast.com/blogs/2010/tv-news/cbs-rejects-gay-themed-super-bowl-ad/|work=Fancast.com|accessdate=5 February 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110310131813/http://www.fancast.com/blogs/2010/tv-news/cbs-rejects-gay-themed-super-bowl-ad|archivedate=10 March 2011}}</ref><ref name=hp-mancrunch>{{cite web|title=ManCrunch SuperBowl [sic] Ad REJECTED: Gay Dating Site Ad Denied By CBS (VIDEO)|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/01/28/mancrunch-superbowl-ad-ga_n_440773.html|work=Huffington Post|publisher=[[AOL]]|accessdate=5 February 2014|first=Danny|last=Shea|date=28 January 2010}}</ref>
In October 2014, the NFL fined player [[Colin Kaepernick]] for wearing pink-colored [[Beats Electronics|Beats]] [[headphone]]s (in observance of [[National Breast Cancer Awareness Month]]) during a post-game press conference, violating rules that prohibit players from displaying the logos of non-sponsors during games, practices, and pre/post-game media appearances. His actions infringed the exclusive sponsorship rights of [[Bose Corporation]], who had become an official sponsor of the NFL as of the 2014 season.<ref name=cnet-colintape/><ref name=wp-nflbeatsban>{{cite web|title=NFL bans players' Beats by Dre headphones on camera because of its Bose deal|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/early-lead/wp/2014/10/05/nfl-bans-players-beats-by-dre-headphones-on-camera-because-of-its-bose-deal/|accessdate=13 October 2014|work=Washington Post|date=5 October 2014}}</ref><ref name=wp-beatsnfl>{{cite web|title=Colin Kaepernick says NFL fined him $10,000 for wearing Beats by Dre headphones|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/early-lead/wp/2014/10/09/colin-kaepernick-says-nfl-fined-him-10000-for-wearing-beats-by-dre-headphones/|accessdate=13 October 2014|work=Washington Post|date=9 October 2014}}</ref> In response to the fine, Kaepernick [[greeking|covered]] the Beats logo on the headphones with [[athletic tape]] during a subsequent press conference.<ref name=cnet-colintape>{{cite web|title=Colin Kaepernick sidesteps NFL Beats ban with masking tape|url=http://www.cnet.com/news/colin-kaepernick-sidesteps-nfl-beats-ban-with-masking-tape/|website=CNET|publisher=CBS Interactive|accessdate=3 February 2015}}</ref>
Prior to [[Super Bowl XLIX]] in Glendale, Arizona, the NFL filed an opposition to a trademark application for "Superb Owl", filed by the organizers of a local running event known as The Night Run. They had planned to hold a "Superb Owl Shuffle 5K" event on the morning of the game, in reference to the "Superb Owl" awards given out during The Night Run. The NFL felt that the trademark was likely to cause confusion with its Super Bowl trademarks, also noting that the event's website, superbowlshuffle.org, was confusingly similar to "[[The Super Bowl Shuffle|Super Bowl Shuffle]]".<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.azcentral.com/story/news/local/scottsdale/2015/08/10/scottsdale-super-owl-race-nfl-trademark-objection/31421093/|title=Race organizers' trademark try of 'Superb Owl' runs afoul of NFL|last=|first=|date=|work=AZcentral|access-date=2017-08-23|language=en}}</ref> The euphemism "Superb Owl" had also appeared as the result of user typos on search queries for the game, on the television series ''[[The Colbert Report]]'' as a satire of the NFL's trademark rules, and during the vandalism of commemorative statues that were put up in [[San Francisco]] during the lead-up to [[Super Bowl 50]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2017/02/03/superb-owl-searches-soar-big-game-approaches/jOTRY9sDC8BwfhBNT96MIK/story.html|title=‘Superb Owl’ searches soar as big game approaches - The Boston Globe|last=|first=|date=|work=Boston Globe|access-date=2017-08-23|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170203171750/http://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2017/02/03/superb-owl-searches-soar-big-game-approaches/jOTRY9sDC8BwfhBNT96MIK/story.html|archive-date=2017-02-03|dead-url=yes}}</ref>
=== Minneapolis sports venues === In September 2010, the [[Minnesota Timberwolves]] basketball team announced that they would install a large billboard sign for [[Sanford Health]] on the exterior of [[Target Center]]. The sign was placed so that it would be visible from within [[Target Field]], home stadium of the [[Minnesota Twins]] baseball team. The Twins have a competing healthcare sponsorship with the [[Mayo Clinic]]. Although it is a city-owned venue, the Timberwolves had the right to sell advertising on the exterior of the arena. Twins president [[Dave St. Peter]] stated that the size of the sign was "shocking", while the timing of the change was criticized for occurring right before the start of the [[2010 Major League Baseball season#Postseason|2010 Major League Baseball postseason]], which would bring national exposure to the venue and the sign.<ref name=minnpost-timbersign>{{cite web|title=Tempest brewing over huge advertising sign being erected on Target Center -- facing Target Field|url=http://www.minnpost.com/cityscape/2010/09/tempest-brewing-over-huge-advertising-sign-being-erected-target-center-facing-targ|website=[[MinnPost]]|accessdate=6 January 2015}}</ref> In October 2011, per an extension of [[Target Corporation]]'s naming rights for the arena, the company was given control over its exterior. The Sanford Health sign was replaced by a new display featuring Target's dog mascot Bullseye, which animates after Twins [[Home run|home runs]].<ref name=startrib-removed>{{cite web|title=Sanford Health's big sign on Target Center coming down soon|url=http://www.startribune.com/business/131104848.html|website=[[Star Tribune]]|location=Minneapolis|accessdate=6 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=At Target Field, a Bullseye View of the Game |first=Thomas |last=Lee |url=http://www.startribune.com/business/145251545.html |website=[[Star Tribune]] |location=Minneapolis |date=30 March 2012 |accessdate=1 April 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6E0529u9h?url=http://www.startribune.com/business/145251545.html |archivedate=28 January 2013 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
The [[Minnesota Vikings]]' [[U.S. Bank Stadium]] faced a similar controversy; because the Minneapolis offices of [[Wells Fargo]], a rival to the new stadium's naming rights sponsor [[U.S. Bank]], are located within the vicinity of the stadium, Wells Fargo agreed to only install "non-mounted," non-illuminated signage on its building, such as letters painted directly onto the roof. After the original agreement was reached, Wells Fargo had asked the team to allow the installation of "raised, illuminated lettering. mounted on beams more than a foot above the roof rather than painted on the roof as agreed upon". Such signage would be visible in overhead views of U.S. Bank Stadium (such as camera shots during event telecasts), Wells Fargo threatened to light the entire rooftops of its offices if the Vikings chose to deny the requested change. In December 2015, the Vikings sued Wells Fargo for violating the agreement, after they began to construct an illuminated sign on their rooftop.<ref name="startrib-wellsfargo">{{cite web|title=Vikings say Wells Fargo's new rooftop signs near U.S. Bank Stadium are too big and bright|url=http://www.startribune.com/minnesota-vikings-say-wells-fargo-s-new-signs-near-u-s-bank-stadium-are-too-big-and-bright/363378351/|website=Star-Tribune|location=Minneapolis|accessdate=6 July 2016}}</ref><ref name="mbj-photobomb">{{cite web|title=Vikings sue Wells Fargo over 'photo bomb' rooftop signs near U.S. Bank Stadium|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/twincities/news/2015/12/23/vikings-sue-wells-fargo-over-photo-bomb-rooftop.html|website=Minneapolis/St. Paul Business Journal|publisher=American City Business Journals|accessdate=6 July 2016}}</ref> On June 23, 2016, Judge [[Donovan W. Frank]] ruled in favor of the Vikings, and ordered Wells Fargo to remove the raised, illuminated signage.<ref name="pioneer-winbattle">{{cite web|title=Vikings win battle over Wells Fargo ‘photo bombing’ of U.S. Bank Stadium|url=http://www.twincities.com/2016/06/23/vikings-win-battle-over-wells-fargo-photo-bombing-of-u-s-bank-stadium/|website=Pioneer Press|accessdate=6 July 2016}}</ref>
=== Ambushes of Apple === In October 2011, [[Samsung]] ambushed the Australian launch of [[Apple Inc.|Apple]]'s [[iPhone 4S]] [[smartphone]] by setting up a [[Pop-up retail|pop-up store]] near Sydney's [[Apple Store]]. At the store, the company sold its competing [[Samsung Galaxy S II|Galaxy S II]] to the first 10 people in line daily at a discount price of $2 [[Australian dollar|AUD]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Samsung plays dirty, ambushes Apple's iPhone 4S launch in Sydney|url=https://thenextweb.com/apple/2011/10/12/samsung-plays-dirty-ambushes-apples-iphone-4s-launch-in-sydney/|publisher=The Next Web|accessdate=18 August 2012}}</ref> Samsung similarly piggybacked the launch of its successor, the [[iPhone 5]], to promote the [[Galaxy S III]] and [[Galaxy Note II]]; the company purchased keyword advertisements for the devices on major search engines, as well as [[Twitter]] and [[YouTube]], thus causing ads for them to appear on searches relating to iPhone 5.<ref name="tnw-iphone5ambush">{{cite web|title=Samsung’s weapons in battle against Apple’s iPhone 5: Google, Twitter and Bing|url=https://thenextweb.com/apple/2012/09/13/samsung-lays-serious-marketing-dollars-ambush-iphone-5-launch/|website=The Next Web|accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref><ref name="businessinsider-killingiphone5">{{cite news|title=Samsung Is Killing The iPhone 5 In Web Video Ads Right Now|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/samsung-is-killing-iphone-5-in-web-video-2012-9|accessdate=27 January 2017|work=Business Insider}}</ref>
The [[Quebec]]-based home improvement chain [[Rona (company)|Rona]] ambushed a billboard sign advertising another Apple product, the [[iPod Nano]], by placing a banner for its [[paint recycling]] services that showed the paint from the devices in the Apple billboard above it falling into cans.<ref name=best-ambush/>
== Impact == [[File:Olympic Stadium (London) illuminated, 3 August 2012.jpg|thumb|right|The organizers of the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] ''([[Olympic Stadium (London)|stadium]] pictured)'' received criticism for their "draconian" anti-ambush marketing rules.<ref name=guardian-olympicbill/><ref name=outlaw-2012/>]]
Moves to control ambush marketing at events have been met with mixed reception: ambush marketing regulations enable the event organizer to prevent competitors from impeding on a company's exclusive rights to serve as an event's sponsor, thus making their sponsorship rights more lucrative.<ref name=wsj-ambushed /><ref name=guardian-brandingpolice /><ref name=sportpro-ambush /> Laws enacted to control ambush advertising practices have proven to be controversial: critics have argued that ambush advertising regulations can inhibit [[Freedom of speech|free expression]] and prevent businesses (such as restaurants, [[sports bar]]s, and [[pub]]s) from even mentioning an event, and that a country's existing [[trademark law]]s can be sufficient to protect organizers' intellectual property without granting them special powers.<ref name=guardian-olympicbill/><ref name=startrib-aclu/>
The [[American Civil Liberties Union]] has opposed "clean zone" policies on several occasions; prior to both [[Super Bowl XLVII]] and the [[2014 Major League Baseball All-Star Game]], the organization respectively sued both the cities of [[New Orleans]] and [[Minneapolis]] for enforcing clean zone laws, arguing that they were [[unconstitutional]] for banning [[protected speech]]. In response to the lawsuit, New Orleans did amend its clean zone ordinance to allow non-commercial protected speech within the clean zones.<ref name=startrib-aclu>{{cite web|title=ACLU sues Minneapolis over All-Star Game "clean zone"|url=http://www.startribune.com/local/blogs/258505291.html|website=Star-Tribune|accessdate=15 October 2014}}</ref><ref name=vice-nosuperbowl/> The NFL has also received criticism for exaggerating the extent of its intellectual property rights under the laws of the United States, aggressively enforcing its trademarks, and failing to take the doctrine of [[fair use]] into account.<ref name=ars-nfloveraggressive>{{cite web|title=The NFL wants you to think these things are illegal|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2015/01/the-nfl-wants-you-to-think-these-things-are-illegal/|website=Ars Technica|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref><ref name=thr-supertrademarks/><ref name=wsj-godvsgridiron/>
During the lead-up to the [[2012 Summer Olympics]], the [[London Organising Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games]] (LOCOG) showed an infamously aggressive stance towards enforcing anti-ambush advertising regulations. The organizing committee's policies and the [[London Olympic Games and Paralympic Games Act 2006]] were criticized by local politicians, along with the [[Chartered Institute of Marketing]], for being overly broad, "draconian," and unnecessary to enforce its exclusive trademark and sponsorship rights.<ref name=guardian-olympicbill>{{cite web|title=Olympic bill under fire|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2006/jan/16/advertising.marketingandpr|accessdate=3 October 2014|work=The Guardian}}</ref><ref name=outlaw-2012>{{cite web|title=Olympic law 'draconian', says marketing body|url=http://www.out-law.com/page-9441|website=Out-Law|accessdate=3 October 2014}}</ref> The press described LOCOG as being a "branding police" due to these enforcement measures; [[EasyJet]] was told by a LOCOG representative that having [[Sally Gunnell]] reprise her pose with the [[Union Jack]] from the [[1992 Summer Olympics|1992 Games]] for an advertisement would constitute an unauthorized association, an art event known as ''The Great Exhibition 2012'' received threats from LOCOG for merely containing "2012" in its name, and athletes were asked to report ambush advertising activities on a special website.<ref name=marketing-brandpolice/><ref name=guardian-brandingpolice/> In contrast, LOCOG allowed the restaurant chain [[Little Chef]] to continue selling its popular "Olympic Breakfast," owing to its long-standing use of the brand since 1994.<ref name=littlechef>{{cite web|title=Little Chef allowed to keep Olympic Breakfast, LOCOG rules|url=http://www.thedrum.co.uk/news/2012/07/23/little-chef-allowed-keep-olympic-breakfast-locog-rules|accessdate=26 July 2012|website=The Drum}}</ref>
It was also argued by critics that LOCOG's policies made it unviable for smaller businesses to promote themselves using the Games, even in support of athletes, as they would need to evaluate whether their marketing materials violate the restrictions on unauthorized associations.<ref name=marketing-brandpolice>{{cite web|title=Branding 'police' mask non-sponsor logos at Olympic venues|url=http://www.marketingmagazine.co.uk/article/1115729/branding-police-mask-non-sponsor-logos-olympic-venues|website=Marketing Magazine (UK)|accessdate=3 January 2015}}</ref><ref name=guardian-brandingpolice>{{cite web|title=Olympics 2012: branding 'police' to protect sponsors' exclusive rights|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2012/apr/13/olympics-2012-branding-police-sponsors|accessdate=3 January 2015|work=The Guardian}}</ref> Additionally, the architecture community strongly criticised the marketing restrictions, citing LOCOG's refusal to allow architectural firms to publicise their work on Olympic venues, including preventing the firms from entering national and international award competitions. LOCOG retained rights to all Olympic marks even after the end of the games until they were transferred to the [[British Olympic Association]] in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2012/jul/11/olympics-marketing-rules-architecture-tessa-jowell?newsfeed=true |title=Olympics marketing rules are damaging British business, says Tessa Jowell |first=Owen |last=Gibson |website=The Guardian |date=11 July 2012 |accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref>
During the [[2016 United States Olympic Trials (track and field)|2016 U.S. Olympic track and field trials]], the apparel company Oiselle received demands by the [[United States Olympic Committee]] (USOC) to remove social media posts congratulating its sponsored athlete [[Kate Grace]] on qualifying for the [[2016 Summer Olympics]]. The USOC considered them to be unauthorized "Olympic-related advertising" because the photos attached to the posts depicted USOC trademarks, including the Olympic rings and the phrase "Road to Rio". Company CEO Sally Bergesen stated that future posts would remove or obscure references to these trademarks, but argued that their depiction were [[De minimis|incidental]] because the offending material appeared in the venue and on the bibs worn by all athletes at the event, making it intractable to avoid depicting them in photos taken there. She also defended the postings as being news reporting on the achievements of its sponsored athletes, and not necessarily promotion for the brand itself.<ref name="fittish-usoctm">{{cite web|title=U.S. Olympic Committee Tells Oiselle To Delete Social Media Posts, Ignores Others|url=http://fittish.deadspin.com/u-s-olympic-committee-tells-oiselle-to-delete-social-m-1783304825|website=Fittish (Deadspin)|publisher=Gawker Media|accessdate=13 July 2016}}</ref><ref name="adweek-2016">{{cite web|title=How the Olympics' New Advertising Rules Will Impact Athletes and Brands in Rio|url=http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/how-olympics-new-advertising-rules-will-impact-athletes-and-brands-rio-172372|website=Adweek|accessdate=13 July 2016}}</ref><ref name="nyt-evade">{{cite web|title=Olympics Ease an Ad Blackout, and Brands Flood the Field|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/04/business/media/olympics-ease-an-ad-blackout-and-brands-flood-the-field.html?_r=0|website=The New York Times|accessdate=13 July 2016}}</ref> The onerous restrictions on the promotion of Olympic athletes were one of the factors behind the [[National Hockey League]]'s decision to prohibit its players from participating in the [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics|men's ice hockey tournaments]] at the [[2018 Winter Olympics]].<ref name="NYTimes20160520">{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/20/sports/hockey/olympics-and-nhl-face-off-over-who-pays-to-insure-players.html?_r=0 | title=Olympics and N.H.L. Face Off Over Who Pays to Insure Players | work=The New York Times | date=19 May 2016 | accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref>
Comedian [[Stephen Colbert]] satirized the USOC policies during a sketch on ''[[The Late Show with Stephen Colbert|The Late Show]]'' aired on the eve of the 2016 opening ceremony, wherein he presented an image of five [[CBS]] logos arranged and coloured like the [[Olympic rings]], and promoted the programme's new "sponsor", Musa Tea (a beverage "brewed from the freshest mint in Morocco's [[Jebel Musa (Morocco)|Musa mountains]]"), which is promoted using the [[hashtag]] "#teamusa".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2016/08/stephen-colbert-rio-olympics-hashtags-donald-trump-video-1201797104/|title=Stephen Colbert Thumbs Nose At Rio Olympics Organizers|last=Moraes|first=Lisa de|date=2016-08-02|work=Deadline|access-date=2017-08-23|language=en-US}}</ref> Colbert also satirized the NFL's "Super Bowl" trademarks in 2014 on his previous series, ''[[The Colbert Report]]'', where he referred to the game as the "Superb Owl", and remarked that "we all know that the winner of the Big Game [[I'm going to Disney World!|goes to]] [[Walt Disney World|Animated Mouse Theme Park]]."<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.thewrap.com/stephen-colbert-finds-loophole-nfl-trademark-get-ready-colbert-report-superb-owl-xlviii-video/|title=Stephen Colbert Finds NFL Trademark Loophole: Prepare for 'Colbert Report' 'Superb Owl XLVIII' (Video)|date=2014-01-28|work=TheWrap|access-date=2017-08-23|language=en-US}}</ref>

''The Ambush Marketing Toolkit'', McGraw-Hill, September 2007. {{ISBN|0-07-013808-7}}. * Cornelius, Steve. [https://www.academia.edu/11380406/Ambush_Marketing_in_Sport "Ambush Marketing in Sport"] 2011/4 [http://www.sportsandtaxation.com/ Global Sports Law and Taxation Reports], 12 (December 2011).

[[File:Beard token.jpg|thumb|right|A Russian beard token from 1705, carried to indicate that the owner had paid the beard tax imposed by Peter the Great]] A '''beard tax''' is one of several taxes introduced throughout history on men who wear [[beard]]s.
== England == In 1535, King [[Henry VIII of England]], who wore a beard himself, introduced a tax on beards. The tax was a graduated tax, varying with the wearer's social position. His daughter, [[Elizabeth I of England]], reintroduced the beard tax, taxing every beard of more than two weeks' growth, although it was poorly enforced.<ref>{{cite book |last=Andrews |first1=William G. |url=http://www.loyalbooks.com/download/text/At-the-Sign-of-the-Barbers-Pole-by-Andrews.txt |format=TXT |title=At the Sign of the Barber's Pole: Studies in Hirsute History |location=Cottingham, Yorkshire, England |publisher=J.R. Tutin |year=1904 |isbn=978-1590210819 |accessdate=2016-12-28 }}</ref> Contemporary documentation of the Tudor beard tax, however, is lacking, and [[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|The National Archives]] has no record of such a tax having been instituted.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://dhhliteraryagency.wordpress.com/2014/11/11/moustaches-whiskers-beards-lucinda-hawksley/ |title=DHH Author Blog: Moustaches, Whiskers & Beards – Lucinda Hawksley |last=Hawksley |first=Lucinda |date=2014-11-11 |accessdate=2016-12-28 }}</ref>
== Russia == [[File:Бородовые знаки 1705-1725.gif|thumb|right|Beard tokens (1725 version above; 1705 version below)]] {{Expand Russian|Бородовой знак|date=December 2016}} In 1698,<ref>{{cite book |last=Corson |first1=Richard |title=Fashions in Hair: The First Five Thousand Years |edition=3rd |location=London |publisher=Peter Owen Publishers |year=2005 |page=220 |isbn=978-0720610932 }}</ref> Emperor [[Peter I of Russia]] instituted a beard tax to [[Government reform of Peter I|bring Russian society in line with Western European models]]. To enforce the ban on beards, the tsar empowered police to forcibly and publicly shave those who refused to pay the tax.<ref>{{cite news |last=Worthington |first=Daryl |url=http://www.newhistorian.com/historys-strangest-tax-peter-great-puts-price-beards/7157/ |title=History’s Strangest Tax? Peter the Great Puts a Price on Beards |work=New Historian |location=London |publisher=Forgotten Books |date=2016-09-04 |accessdate=2016-12-27 }}</ref> Resistance to going clean shaven was widespread with many believing that it was a religious requirement for a man to wear a beard.<ref>{{citation |last=Walsh |first=Devan |title=Analysis of Peter the Great's Social Reforms and the Justification of the Reactions from the General Public |year=2015 |url=http://www.wou.edu/history/files/2015/08/Walsh-Devan.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2016-12-27 }}</ref> The tax levied depended upon the status of the bearded man: Those associated with the Imperial Court, military, or government were charged 60 [[Russian ruble|rubles]] annually; wealthy merchants were charged 100 rubles per year while other merchants and townsfolk were charged 60 rubles per year; Muscovites were charged 30 rubles per year; and peasants were charged two half-kopeks every time they entered a city.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.runivers.ru/bookreader/book9812/#page/283/mode/1up |title=Указ Императора Петра I — О бритiи бородъ и усовъ всякаго чина людямъ, кромѣ поповъ и дьяконовъ, о взятiи пошлины съ тѣхъ, которые сего исполнить не захотятъ, и о выдачѣ заплатившимъ пошлину знаковъ |language=Russian |trans-title=Decree of Tsar Peter I — Concerning Beards and Mustaches of Certain Ranks of People, Exempting Priests and Deacons, and Levying a Fee and Issuing a Mark to Those Who Do Not Wish to Shave |date=1705-01-16 |accessdate=2016-12-27 }}</ref>
=== Beard token === Those who paid the tax were required to carry a "beard token" (Бородовой знак).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://iipdigital.usembassy.gov/st/english/article/2009/11/20091124175845fjreffahcs0.5918848.html |title=Smithsonian Rare Russian Coin Collection Seeks Exhibition Sponsor |last=Schaffer |first=Jonathan |publisher=[[U.S. Department of State]] |date=2009-11-25 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111013182924/http://www.america.gov/st/eur-english/2009/November/20091124175845FJreffahcS0.5918848.html |archivedate=2011-10-13 |accessdate=2016-12-28 }}</ref> This was a copper or silver token with a [[Double-headed eagle|Russian Eagle]] on the reverse and on the [[obverse and reverse|obverse]] the lower part of a face with nose, mouth, whiskers, and beard. Several different versions were minted between the issuance of the decree and its lifting in 1772.<ref>{{cite news |last=Mancini |first=Mark |url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/55772/time-peter-great-declared-war-facial-hair |title=The Time Peter the Great Declared War on Facial Hair |work=Mental Floss |date=2014-03-29 |accessdate=2016-12-27 }}</ref> The common round version was inscribed with the words "money taken" (ДЕНГИ ВЗѦТЫ) on the obverse and the date in [[Cyrillic numerals]] (҂АѰЕ ГОДѸ, "Year 1705") on the reverse. A rhomboid version issued in 1725 was smooth on the reverse with the phrase "beard tax taken" (СБОРОДЫ ПОШЛИНА ВЗЯТА) on the obverse and "the beard is a superfluous burden" (БОРОДА ЛИШНѦѦ ТѦГОТА) on the [[coin edge|edge]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Florensky |first1=Pavel |authorlink=Pavel Florensky |title=The Pillar and Ground of the Truth: An Essay in Orthodox Theodicy in Twelve Letters |location=Princeton, New Jersey |publisher=Princeton University Press |year=1997 |page=535 |isbn=978-0691032436 }}</ref><ref>{{cite encyclopedia |encyclopedia=[[Brockhaus and Efron Encyclopedic Dictionary]] |title=Бородовой знак |url=http://dic.academic.ru/dic.nsf/brokgauz_efron/15302/%D0%91%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B9 |year=1907 |location=St. Petersburg, Russia |accessdate=2016-12-27 }}</ref> [[Walter Hawkins (ship broker)|Walter Hawkins]] published a paper in 1845 illustrating an example of the token from his own collection, and describing the history of the tax in Russia.<ref>{{cite book|last=Hawkins|first=Walter|editor=John Yonge Akerman|title=The Numismatic Chronicle and Journal of the Numismatic Society|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-3s9AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA153|accessdate=27 December 2016|volume=Vol. VII|year=1845|publisher=Taylor & Walton|location=London|pages=153–155|chapter=Russian Beard Token}}</ref>
